awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Co-Design of Networking and Decentralized Control to Enable Aerial Networks in an Uncertain Airspace
awd_abstract_narration:
Airborne networking, unlike the networking of fixed sensors, mobile devices, and slowly-moving vehicles, is very challenging because of the high mobility, stringent safety requirements, and uncertain airspace environment. Airborne networking is important because of the growing complexity of the National Airspace System with the integration of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).  This project develops an innovative new theoretical framework for cyber-physical systems (CPS) to enable airborne networking, which utilizes direct flight-to-to-flight communication for flexible information sharing, safe maneuvering, and coordination of time-critical missions.

This project uses an innovative co-design approach that exploits the mutual benefits of networking and decentralized mobility control in an uncertain heterogeneous environment. The approach departs from the usual perspective that views physical mobility as communication constraints, communication as constraints for decentralized mobility control, and uncertain environment as constraints for both. Instead, approach taken here proactively exploits the constraints, uncertainty, and new structures with information to enable high-performance designs. The features of the co-design such as scalability, fast response, trackability, and robustness to uncertainty advance the core CPS science on decision-making for large-scale networks under uncertainty. 

The technological advances developed in this research will contribute to multiple fields, including mobile networking, decentralized control, experiment design, and general real-time decision making under uncertainty for CPS. Technology transfer will be pursued through close collaboration with industries and national laboratories. This novel research direction will also serve as a unique backdrop to inspire the CPS workforce. New teaching materials will benefit the future CPS workforce by equipping them with a knowledge base in networking and control. Broad outreach and dissemination activities that involve undergraduate student societies, K-12 school teaching, and public events, all stemming from the PI's current efforts, will be enhanced.

por.por_cntn:
We are very thankful to the NSF CPS program for the support of research on developing the co-design framework of networking and decentralized control to enable aerial networks in an uncertain airspace. Through the project span (under project numbers 1453722 and 1714519), we have produced fruitful results in multiple pioneering research directions summarized as follows.

1.The CPS Networking and Distributed Control Co-Design Methodology:   We developed a CPS co-design framework that exploits the mutual benefits of networking and decentralized mobility control in an uncertain heterogeneous environment. The core of the co-design framework are random mobility models widely used in the communication field, which fall under the category of random switching systems. The approach departs from the usual perspective that views physical mobility as communication constraints, communication as constraints for decentralized mobility control, and uncertain environment as constraints for both. Instead, approach taken here proactively exploits the constraints, uncertainty, and new structures with information to enable high-performance designs. The features of the co-design such as scalability, fast response, trackability, and robustness to uncertainty advance the core CPS science on decision-making for large-scale networks under uncertainty.

2.Optimal Decision-making under High-dimensional Uncertainties: We developed a method that effectively evaluates system performance under high-dimensional uncertainties, called M-PCM-OFFD (integrated Multivariate Probabilistic Collocation Method and Orthogonal Fractional Factorial Design Method), as a key step toward real-time decision-making. The method explores the statistical knowledge of uncertain parameters to smartly choose only a limited number of simulations, which can be used to precisely predict output statistics. With this method, the computational load (measured by the number of simulations) is drastically reduced and breaks the curse of dimensionality.  The method is further integrated with stochastic optimal control and reinforcement learning to achieve robust and scalable decision-making under uncertainty. These results contribute to the CPS research with a simple scalable and effective procedure for real-time decision-making under high-dimensional uncertainty and has been applied to a wide range of CPS applications.

3.Airborne Network and UAV-carried Wi-Fi for Emergency Response: The above theoretical results on CPS were applied to Airborne networking, an emerging CPS application area. We contributed to this field with the evaluation and design foundation of networking strategies. In addition, we developed prototype systems for UAVs to deliver Wi-Fi signals in the air.  This prototype for drone-carried on-demand systems provides reliable and high-speed Wi-Fi signals promptly when an emergency occurs. The system can be used in for instance, wildfires, where drones can be dispatched to transmit back over long-distance real-time videos of fire condition. The system can help to reduce cost and information delay and hence shorten response time.

The results have been documented in over 70 publications (6 reported under 1453722 and over 60 reported under 1714519), including one edited book, two book chapters and top journals across communication, control and applications domains, such as IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, Automatica, IEEE Transactions on Systems Man, and Cybernetics, IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems, IEEE Transactions Intelligent Transportation Systems, IEEE Transactions Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics, and IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology.

The results have also led to technology transfer outcomes. It has led to two patents (pending approval) and projects with Toyota Motors, Ford Motors, Lockheed Martin, ARO and ONR in other application domains such as autonomous driving, underwater vehicle networks, human-robot teaming, and microgrid control.  

The support from this project also led to significant education and outreach outcomes. It supported 7 PhD students including 4 who have graduated. 4 of the PhD students are female, 3 female Ph.D students are now professors, and one Ph.D. student received the CAREER award. This grant also supported a number of postdoc, master, and undergraduate students. A new course on Cyber-Physical Systems was established at UTA since 2017 and a graduate certificate on Cyber-Physical Systems was launched this year. The PI also delivered over 70 invited talks and demonstrations on the project that significantly benefitted the broad public. Thee AI for Good webinar on “Unleashing autonomous drones for disaster risk reduction” delivered on 10/13/2022 alone had more than 400 participants.

The support from this project also allowed the PI to actively participate in professional societies. The PI is currently a member of the Board of Governors of the IEEE Control Systems Soceity, and a member of the Execution Committee of the IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Society.  The PI is also currently an Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems, IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems, IEEE Transactions on Mechatronics, Unmanned Systems, Journal of Advanced Control for Applications, Unmanned Systems and Journal of Intelligent & Robotic Systems. The PI has been on organizing committee for many conferences, including ACC 2022.
